articles.title: Phishing Template Topic Glossary
articles.body:
Note:We’ve added advanced features to phishing templates! All accounts will be opted in to phishing template advanced features in 2025. For more information, see our Phishing Templates Advanced Features Guide.

Some phishing templates are available in multiple languages for better localization support. For more information on phishing template languages, see our Localization Guide.

The glossary below will provide a description of what types of emails are in each phishing template topic.

JUMP TO:A - B - C - D - E - F - G - H - I - L - M - O - P - Q - R - S - T - W

A

Account Notifications

This topic contains templates that claim to contain account notifications from various service providers. Many of the sender email domains for these templates spoof well-known organizations.

Attachments with Macros

Contains templates that have attachments with embedded macros. These often masquerade as invoices, resumes, or important business documents requiring immediate attention.

B

Banking

This topic contains templates impersonating popular banks and financial institutions. This topic also contains generic banking templates, such as transaction and confirmation activities. Many of the sender email domains for these templates spoof well-known organizations.

Baseline Templates

This topic is dedicated to revealing an accurate Phish-Prone Percentage of your organization when performing a baseline Phishing Security Test. These templates contain generic and organization-specific emails that could fool almost anyone. Subjects include anything from Internal IT emails spoofing your own domain to social media activity notifications.

Brand Knock-Offs

This topic contains phishing templates impersonating major brands, social media platforms, and retailers. The brand names are frequently misspelled, a major phishing red flag.

Business Communication

This is our largest phishing template topic category. This topic includes typical communications that employees might receive. Subjects of these emails include theoretical invoices, purchase orders, requests for information, shared files, and more. These templates typically don’t spoof companies and will come from a wide assortment of sender email domains.

Business Finance

This topic contains communications employees might receive regarding payments, payment information, bills, bank accounts, and invoices. These templates frequently try to trick users into thinking a bill is overdue or that they owe payment.

C

CEO Fraud

This topic contains communications that appear to come from your organization’s CEO. The CEO may ask for a favor, payment, or a meeting. These emails spoof your own domain.

Compliance

This topic contains phishing templates that ask the user to perform a task to comply with organizational policies or rules. This topic can encompass signing work documents, finishing training, complying with IT updates, and more.

Controversial

This topic contains controversial content that might be considered offensive or inappropriate to some organizations, but others may find these templates appropriate and helpful to use in an aggressive simulated phishing campaign.

Current Event of the Month

This topic will contain a single Current Event or Holiday template, hand-selected by the Content team each month to ensure that you're getting a high-quality, timely, and relevant template. Review the Current Events and Holiday template topic descriptions to understand the types of templates that may be selected for this topic.

For more information about this topic, see our Current Event of the Week or Month Template Topics Overview article.

Current Event of the Week

This topic will contain a single Current Event or Holiday template, hand-selected by the Content team each week to ensure that you're getting a high-quality, timely, and relevant template. See the Current Events and Holiday template topic descriptions to understand the types of templates that may be selected for this topic.

For more information about this topic, see our Current Event of the Week or Month Template Topics Overview article.

Current Events

This topic contains a variety of templates appropriate for current events, news, matters, and occasions. Templates include anything from national headline alerts, both real and fake, spoofing major news channels, popular app downloads, or shopping discounts and coupons.

Current Holiday

This topic contains emails that impersonate retailers with holiday sales and deals. They frequently contain links to shopping discounts and coupons.

Cybersecurity Awareness Month

We create four phishing templates for each Cybersecurity Awareness Month in October. Each phishing template is an example of a common cybersecurity threat, such as social engineering and malicious URLs. For more information, see our Engage Users During Cybersecurity Awareness Month article.

D

Data Breach

This topic allows you to spear-phish users who have been part of specific data breaches. Each template spoofs a unique organization that has had a large-scale data breach incident.

Each template includes a corresponding data entry landing page. So, you can test your users' susceptibility to clicking a link and their proneness to entering sensitive information.

This topic is intended to be used with Email Exposure Check Pro (EEC Pro), but it can be used in any type of phishing campaign.

For more information, see our Data Breach Topic Guide.

Data Privacy

This topic includes templates that impersonate major technology platforms, alerting users of privacy issues in their accounts. Some examples include alerting users that they’ve shared personal information, their security settings have changed, or that there’s suspicious activity in their accounts.

E

Education

This topic includes education-related templates involving college and graduate matters, high school news alerts, teacher incentives, pay raises, and student loan information. The majority of these templates apply to anyone working or involved in the education industry.

Email Security

This topic includes templates that alert users that their email account settings have been compromised or changed.

Entertainment

This topic includes templates that alert users about entertainment-related events, celebrities, places, and platforms.

Events

This topic includes templates that alert users about events that can be work- and entertainment-related.

F

Financial Services

This topic includes templates concerning the status of finances. Examples include bank account notifications, cryptocurrency notifications, and emails spoofing well-known financial institutions.

G

Government

This topic contains templates spoofing state, local, and federal governments, regarding issues such as speeding tickets, court summons, jury duty, and criminal activity notifications. The sender email addresses in these templates spoof government domains.

H

Healthcare

This topic includes healthcare-related templates involving insurance and coverage matters, medical files, medical bills, and appointment reminders. The majority of these templates apply to anyone with health insurance.

Holidays & Celebrations

This topic contains templates relevant to any upcoming holidays. Examples include coupons for Christmas shopping, sales for President’s Day, and real or fake news stories in relation to specific holidays.

Human Resources

This topic consists of categories typically handled by Human Resources departments.

I

IT

This topic contains various Information Technology-themed subjects, including email account matters, antivirus notifications, and security matters. Many of the sender email addresses for these templates spoof well-known IT organizations, and there are some sender email addresses that spoof your own domain.

Information & Reading

This topic contains various information-related subjects, such as documents that the user must read and review.

Internet Use

This topic contains a variety of phishing emails related to well-known websites, including those related to retail, entertainment, and business organizations.

L

Legal

This topic was created for those in the law or legal industry, and many of the available templates contain legal language.

M

Mail Notifications/Server Messages

This topic contains automated messages that users would normally receive from their mail client. The template content typically references mailbox storage, bounced or pending email alerts, and required system updates.

Mobile Apps

This topic includes phishing emails related to mobile apps. Examples include app updates, policy updates, and invitations to join apps.

Mobile Devices

This topic includes phishing emails related to mobile devices and several mobile apps. Examples include upgrades to mobile devices, software updates, and app updates. There’s some overlap with the Mobile Apps topic.

O

Online Services

This topic contains emails from various well-known online services, including shopping, entertainment, apps, financial, and security services. The majority of the sender email addresses in these templates include spoofed domains of very popular websites and applications that your users will recognize.

Outdoor/Sporting Goods

This topic includes templates replicating emails from well-known outdoor/sporting goods distributors. The emails in this topic contain announcements of store sales and coupons from popular manufacturers.

P

Passwords & Authentication

This topic includes templates impersonating brands that request authentication or resetting passwords and login information. The emails attempt to get the user to click on a link to view account information, log in to a service, or reset their login information.

Phish Alert Button Test

This topic includes one email asking users to test the Phish Alert Button’s (PAB) functionality. For more information regarding this email and its purpose, visit our Phish Alert Button (PAB) Test Email Overview article.

Phishing for Sensitive Information

Templates in this topic have Phishing for Sensitive Information landing pages assigned to them. If users click on any links in these Phishing Security Test emails, they will be redirected to a landing page with a form asking them to enter sensitive data. If the user does enter data, a failure for this action will be recorded in the system.

For more details on Phishing for Sensitive Information, email templates, and landing pages, see our Data Entry Landing Pages Guide.

Phone Services

This topic includes emails impersonating phone services, both mobile and landline. Example emails include invoices, phone upgrades, voicemails, call services, and more.

Q

QR Code

This topic contains templates with a QR code as the Phishing Security Test attack vector. A QR code redirects users to a website or attachment. For more information about QR code phishing, see our QR Code Phishing Security Tests (PSTs) Guide.

R

Real Estate

This topic contains templates specific to email exchanges found in the real estate industry, such as buyer closing documents and loan information.

Reply-To

The emails in this topic of templates don’t contain any links or attachments and will only test the user on whether or not they’ll reply to a phishing email. You can enable the console to track replies to Phishing Security Test emails when you set up your phishing campaign. If you enable this feature and your user replies to any of the Phishing Security Test emails, this will be recorded as a failure in the console.

For more on reply-to phishing, see our Reply-To Phishing Guide.

Reported Phishes of the Week

This topic consists of the top ten phishing emails reported to us by users of the Phish Alert Button. This topic contains ten new emails every week. The sender domains vary in this topic and include, but are not limited to, those that spoof popular companies and those that spoof your own organization's domain.

For more information about the Reported Phishes of the Week, see our Reported Phishes of the Week Topic Overview article.

S

Seasonal

This template topic includes phishing emails related to deals, days, events, and scenarios that take place at certain times of the year.

Shipments & Deliveries

This topic includes templates impersonating retailers and shipping companies that claim the user has incoming deliveries and shipments, has missed deliveries, or has a package that can’t be delivered.

Shopping & Food

This topic includes templates related to retailers, encompassing shopping and food services.

Social Media

This topic consists of templates for spoofing all types of social media sites and applications. The templates include subjects such as invites to join, confirmation of your account, resetting your password, and notifying you of new messages you’ve received.

Sports

This topic includes templates related to sports, exercise, and gaming.

T

Travel & Transportation

This topic includes templates related to impersonating travel websites, air travel services, rideshare websites, major car brands, major hotel chains, and more.

W

WiFi

This topic includes templates related to Wi-Fi services and access.

articles.body:
Tip: Join the KnowBe4 Community! In the community, you can connect, share knowledge, and collaborate on new ideas with other admins, partners, and employees. For more information, see our KnowBe4 Community Guide.

If you’re brand new to KnowBe4, this article will help you get started with setting up your KSAT console, a platform that provides security awareness training and simulated phishing. Steps one and two are required, and steps three to five are optional but recommended.

Step One: Whitelist Our Mail Servers

Before you start phishing and training your users, you’ll need to whitelist our mail servers. Whitelisting will ensure our Phishing Security Tests (PSTs) and training notifications reach your users’ inboxes. To learn more about whitelisting KnowBe4, see our Whitelisting Guide. 

If you have any questions or need further assistance, contact our support team.

Step Two: Add Your Users

You’ll need to add your users' email addresses to your KSAT console to set up phishing and training campaigns. There are a few different options for importing your users' information into your console. You can use one of these three available methods to make user management an easy and automated process:

  1. Active Directory Integration (ADI): If you’re using Active Directory, we recommend setting up ADI to maintain your user list automatically. Once ADI is set up, your KSAT console will automatically update user and group information based on data received from your Active Directory (AD). To learn more about setting up ADI, see our Active Directory Integration (ADI) Configuration Guide.

  2. System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM): KnowBe4's SCIM integration enables seamless user management in your KSAT console by using data from your SCIM identity provider (IdP). To learn more about configuring SCIM for your KnowBe4 console, see our SCIM Configuration Guide.

  3. Google User Provisioning (GUP): This integration enables automatic synchronization of user data between Google Workspace and your KnowBe4 console. If you’d like to import users directly from your Google account into your KnowBe4 console, we recommend looking at our Google User Provisioning (GUP) Guide.

Alternatively, you can add users manually or import them with a CSV file. For further information, see our Import Users with a CSV File article.

You can choose how to group your users, such as grouping them by department or location. You can also target groups with phishing and training campaigns and allow groups to compete against each other on leaderboards.

To learn more about adding your users, see the Adding Users section of our Users and Groups guide.

Step Three: Customize Your Account

You can customize your account and LX from your Account Settings. Here, you can add your organization’s logo, set a theme color for your LX, and set your business days and hours. To learn more about customizing your account, view our Add Your Company Logo, Logo URL, and Brand Color to Your Console article.

To learn more about setting up your business days and hours, see our Set Up Your Account’s Time Zone, Business Days, and Hours article.

Step Four: Set Up Multi-Factor Authentication

You can enable MFA to provide an extra layer of security and protect your organization's account information. This step is optional but recommended.

To learn more about setting up MFA, see our Enable Two-Factor or Multi-Factor Authentication on My Account article.

Step Five: Customize a Landing Page

Your users will see a default landing page if they fail your PSTs. You can customize this experience by adding your logo to one of our pre-made landing pages, or you can create your own landing page.

After customizing or creating a landing page, you can set a default landing page in the Phishing section of your Account Settings. You’ll also have the option to select a landing page when setting up a phishing campaign or editing email templates.

For more information about landing pages, see our Create and Edit Email Templates and Landing Pages or Best Practices: Choosing a Landing Page article.

articles.name: Set Up an Ongoing Phishing Test
articles.title: Set Up an Ongoing Phishing Test
articles.body:
Note:We’ve added advanced features to phishing templates! All accounts will be opted in to phishing template advanced features in 2025. For more information, see our Phishing Templates Advanced Features Guide.

Once you've trained your users with your first security awareness training campaign, we recommend that you set up an ongoing phishing campaign. Depending on how often you train your users, you can set the campaign to send a test weekly, bi-weekly, monthly, or quarterly.

As a best practice, we recommend phishing your users at least once per month. For high risk users, we recommend bi-weekly testing. Regular phishing tests will allow your users to practice the skills they’ve learned in their security awareness training.

To set up an ongoing phishing campaign, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account and navigate to the Phishing tab.
  2. Click the + Create Phishing Campaign button.
  3. On the New Phishing Campaign page, create your campaign using the recommended settings listed below:

    1. Campaign Name: Enter a name for your phishing campaign here. This field is required.
    2. Send to: Click All Users if you would like to test all users. Or, if you only want to test specific users, click Specific Groups and select the groups you would like to test.
    3. Template Topics: From the first drop-down menu, select the template topics with which you would like to test your users. Use the Set Template Language check box to select the languages you want to use in this phishing campaign. If multiple languages are selected, users will receive templates in any of the selected languages. This setting will override the account’s default phishing language and the language set in the user’s profile. When this check box is selected, the Language Override drop-down menu will appear. You can select a maximum of five languages.
    4. Difficulty Rating: By default, this setting is set to All Ratings. If you would like to set a difficulty rating for the tests that will be sent to your users, you can select any of the options from the drop-down menu.
    5. Template Selection: Select Full Random. These settings will ensure that your users receive different phishing tests.
    6. Phish Link Domain: By default, this setting is set to Random Domain. We recommend that you do not change this setting.
    7. Landing Page: You can select a specific landing page that you would like to use for all the phishing tests in this campaign, or you can leave this setting set to Default Landing Pages. For more information about our available landing pages, see our Best Practices: Choosing a Landing Page article or our Landing Page Category Glossary.
    8. Frequency: You can select Weekly, Bi-weekly, Monthly, or Quarterly, depending on how often you train your users.
    9. Start Time: Set the date, time, and time zone you would like your phishing campaign to start. Your default time zone is the one set in your Account Settings.
    10. Sending Period: Select Send emails over… and set a timeframe of at least three business days. Setting a time period of at least three business days will ensure that your users don’t receive the tests all at once and can’t warn other users about the test. Depending on the Frequency option you selected, we recommend sending emails over one week for bi-weekly campaigns and over three weeks for monthly campaigns.
    11. Define Business Days and Hours: By default, your campaign will only send emails during the business hours set in your Account Settings. You can change the hours your emails are sent by entering a start and end time in this field. You can also choose what days you would like emails to be sent by selecting the date check boxes.
    12. Track Replies to Phishing Emails: You can select this check box if you would like to track your users' replies to phishing test emails. We recommend that you only select this check box for reply-to phishing campaigns. For more information about reply-to phishing, see our Reply-to Phishing Guide.
    13. Track Activity: We recommend that you track activity for at least three days.
    14. Add Clickers to: You have the option to add users who fail the phishing test to a selected group. You can then add this group of users to a remedial training campaign at a later date. For more information about remedial training, see our Create a Remedial Training Campaign article.
    15. Send an email report to account admins after each phishing test: Select this check box if you would like account admins to receive an email when each phishing test is complete.
    16. Hide from Reports: Select this check box to hide the phishing campaign from user profiles and phishing reports. Hidden campaigns will not impact Risk Scores or Phish-prone Percentages. We recommend using this option when running a test campaign for whitelisting or other phishing functionality tests.
    17. Send SecurityTips that reveal missed Social Engineering indicators for phishing failures: Customers with a SecurityCoach subscription can send SecurityTips to users that reveal missed Social Engineering Indicators (SEIs) for phishing failures. This feature lets users receive real-time coaching about the red flags they missed after a simulated phishing test failure. For more information, please visit our Real-Time Coaching With Social Engineering Indicators (SEI) article in the Knowledge Base.
  4. Once you are satisfied with your settings, click Create Campaign.

articles.name: Update User List with Active Users
articles.title: Update User List with Active Users
articles.body:
If you are not using user provisioning to maintain your console's user list, you can use a combination of the Archive Users option and the CSV Import tool to update your active users. When users are archived, they are no longer considered Active Users, but their data is still available in the console.

Important: Do not use this method if you have a training campaign that allows users to take courses multiple times. Archiving and reimporting users will re-enroll them in these training campaigns. The user's original enrollment and completion data will still be available, but they will show as enrolled in the same training again. If this issue occurs, we suggest checking out this article for directions on removing the re-enrolled users.  

To update your active users, follow the steps below:

  1. Prepare a CSV file that contains the current employees who you would like to keep as Active in the console. See our How Do I Import Users with a CSV File? article for more information.
  2. In your KnowBe4 console, navigate to the Users tab. 
  3. From the header of the Users List, click on Download CSV.
  4. Open the downloaded CSV file and delete all columns, except for column A. Keep only the Email column with your users' email addresses. Be sure to also remove the headers of all the deleted columns, not just the data within them.
  5. Save the edited CSV file. 
  6. In your KnowBe4 console, from the header of the Users List, click on Bulk Archive.
  7. From the window that appears, click Browse and upload the edited CSV file.
  8. Choose your notification settings, then click Archive. 
  9. Once all of your users are archived, go to Users > Import Users and click on CSV Import.
  10. Click Browse and upload the CSV file from Step 1—it should contain the current employees who you would like to include as Active users.
  11. Choose your notification settings, then click Import Users.
  12. All of the users in the imported CSV will be restored, along with their past data. Any user not included in the imported CSV file will remain archived.

articles.name: Whitelist by Email Header in Google Workspace
articles.title: Whitelist by Email Header in Google Workspace
articles.body:
Note: Due to upcoming changes from Google, we recommend using Direct Message Injection (DMI) as your default whitelisting configuration. For more information about these changes, see Google's Gmail updates.

If your organization uses Google Workspace, you can whitelist by email header. To whitelist by email header, you'll need to apply a Content Compliance rule to emails that contain KnowBe4's email header. This rule will allow our simulated phishing emails to be delivered to your user's inboxes.

Important: To ensure that your user opens are being tracked properly, you may need to add our phish link domains to your Googe Workspace’s Image URL proxy allowlist. For more information, see Google’s Set up an image URL proxy allowlist article.
Note:We only recommend this setting if your organization uses a cloud-based spam filter for Google Workspace. If you're using Google Workspace for your email without an additional spam filter, you can instead whitelist by IP address. For more information, see our Whitelisting by IP Address in Google Workspace article. You will also need to whitelist KnowBe4's IP addresses or hostnames in your cloud-based spam filter to make sure emails are delivered successfully.
Note:This article reflects our most up-to-date best practices for whitelisting with your provider. Please be aware that your mail service provider may make changes to how their systems analyze our emails at any time. If you are having issues whitelisting using the procedure below, contact our support team.

To whitelist KnowBe4 by email header in Google Workspace, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Google Admin account and click Apps.
  2. Click Google Workspace.
  3. In the Showing status for apps in all organizational units area, click Gmail.
  4. In the Gmail area, click Compliance.
  5. Navigate to the Content Compliance section.
  6. Click Add a rule.
    Note:If you have previously created a Content Compliance rule, this option will be called Add Another Rule.
  7. In the Email messages to affect field, select the Inbound checkbox and the Internal - receiving check box.
  8. Under the Expressions tab, click the first drop-down menu.
  9. From the first drop-down menu, select if ANY of the following match the message.
  10. Click Add.
  11. Undate the settings in the Add expressions that describe the content you want to search for in each message area. For more information about these settings, see the screenshot and list below:
    1. From the first drop-down menu, select Advanced content match.
    2. In Location field, select Full headers.
    3. In the Match type field, select Contains text.
    4. In the Content field, enter the header text. The default KnowBe4 header is "X-PHISHTEST".
      Note:For enhanced security, we recommend that you change the default header to a custom header or header token. You can change the header settings in your KSAT Account Settings. For more information, see our Account Settings Guide article.
    5. Click SAVE.
  12. In the If the above expressions match, do the following field, select the Bypass spam filter for this message check box under Spam.

We recommend setting up a test phishing campaign for yourself or a small group of users. This test phishing campaign can help ensure that your whitelisting was successful. The setting may take up to an hour to deploy to all users so wait at least an hour before testing. If you experience whitelisting issues after following the steps above, contact our support team.

Note:If your organization uses Google Workspace, you’ll also need to disable the return-path header in your KSAT Account Settings before sending phishing tests. For more information, see our How to Change the Return-Path Header in Your Account Settings.
Tip: To ensure that you have whitelisted correctly, see our How to Verify You Have Whitelisted KnowBe4 Correctly article.

articles.name: Add KnowBe4 to Your Sender Policy Framework (SPF) Record
articles.title: Add KnowBe4 to Your Sender Policy Framework (SPF) Record
articles.body:
A Sender Policy Framework (SPF) record is a list of mail servers and domains that are allowed to send emails on your behalf. Adding KnowBe4 to your SPF records allows us to send simulated phishing emails on your behalf and reduces the chance that these emails will be marked as spam or phishing.

Note:Before you add KnowBe4 to your SPF record, you’ll need to enable the Overwrite Fixed Return-path Address with Sender Address setting found in your KSAT Account Settings. For more information, see our Change the Return-Path Header in Your Account Settings article.

To allow KnowBe4's mail servers to send emails on your behalf, add the following line of text to your SPF record:

include:_spf.psm.knowbe4.com

For an example of an SPF record that includes the line of text, see below. The following example uses Google Workspace as the mail server and our US IP addresses:

v=spf1 include:_spf.google.com include:_spf.psm.knowbe4.com ~all

After you update your SPF records, we recommend that you send yourself a test phishing email that spoofs your domain. If you have successfully added KnowBe4 to your SPF record, the email should not go to your Spam folder or be flagged as malicious.

Add KnowBe4’s IP Addresses to Your SPF Record

If you have already added 10 DNS lookups to your SPF record, you’ll need to add our IP addresses to your SPF record. For a list of our IP addresses, see our Whitelisting Guide.

For an example of an SPF record that uses our IP addresses, see below. The following example uses Google Workspace as the mail server:

v=spf1 include:_spf.google.com ip4:23.21.109.197 ip4:23.21.109.212 ip4:147.160.167.0/26 ~all

After you update your SPF records, we recommend that you send yourself a test phishing email that spoofs your domain. If you have successfully added KnowBe4 to your SPF record, the email should not go to your Spam folder or be flagged as malicious.

articles.name: Enable SAML Single Sign-on (SSO) with Microsoft Entra ID
articles.title: Enable SAML Single Sign-on (SSO) with Microsoft Entra ID
articles.body:
In this article, you'll learn how to configure single sign-on (SSO) for your KnowBe4 account with Microsoft Entra ID. When you configure SSO, you'll be able to assign users to KnowBe4 in Microsoft Entra ID. Then, the users will be able to log in to their KnowBe4 Learner Experience (LX) by using Microsoft Entra ID. 

See the sections below to learn how to configure SSO for KnowBe4 with Microsoft Entra ID. 

Note: To complete the steps in this article, you'll need to have a Microsoft Entra ID subscription.

Add the KnowBe4 Application to Microsoft Entra ID

To start configuring SSO with Microsoft Entra ID, you'll need to add the KnowBe4 application to your Microsoft Entra ID account. 

To add the KnowBe4 application to your Microsoft Entra ID account, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Microsoft Entra ID admin account.
  2. From the navigation panel, navigate to Enterprise applications > All applications.
  3. In the top-left corner of the page, click the + New application button.
  4. In the Add from the gallery field, enter "KnowBe4."
  5. Select the KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training application.
  6. In the window that opens, enter your preferred name for the app.
  7. Click the Add button at the bottom of the window. 
  8. In the navigation panel, select the Single sign-on tab.
  9. Select the SAML method. 

Next, obtain your unique KnowBe4 SSO Sign in URL. You'll need this information to configure SSO in Microsoft Entra ID. 

To obtain your SSO Sign in URL, follow the steps below:

  1. In a new window or tab, log in to your KnowBe4 account. 
  2. In the top-right corner of the page, click your email address.
  3. Select Account Settings.
  4. Navigate to Account Integrations > SAML.
  5. Locate your unique SSO Callback (ACS) URL and SSO Sign in URL. In step 3b below, you'll need to copy and paste this information into Microsoft Entra ID. 

Finally, finish configuring SSO in Microsoft Entra ID by following the steps below:

  1. Return to the Microsoft Entra ID portal. 
  2. In the Basic SAML Configuration section, click the pencil icon. 
  3. Edit the fields on this page. For more information about the mandatory fields, see the screenshot and information below:
    1. In the Identifier field, enter "KnowBe4" if you have not generated a unique Entity ID in your account settings. Otherwise, enter your unique Entity ID.
      Important: KnowBe4 is case-sensitive.
    2. In the Reply URL text field, enter the unique SSO Callback (ACS) URL you obtained in step 5 above. For example, enter "https://training.knowbe4.com/auth/saml/xxxxxxxxxxxx/callback".
    3. In the Sign on URL text field, enter the unique SSO Sign in URL you obtained in step 5 above. For example, enter "https://training.knowbe4.com/auth/saml/xxxxxxxxxxxx".
    Note: You only need to fill out the other fields on the Basic SAML Configuration page of your Microsoft Entra ID portal in specific circumstances. For example, if you're using multi-factor authentication (MFA) for Microsoft Entra ID, you'll need to add your callback link to the Relay State field.
  4. After you fill out the fields on this page, click the Save button.
  5. In the User Attributes & Claims section, click the pencil icon to edit the attributes.
  6. Delete the attributes listed below:
    • givenname
    • surname
    • emailaddress
    • name
  7. Click the pencil icon to edit the Unique User Identifier attribute.
  8. In the Source attribute field, make sure the attribute is user.userprincipalname. If you would like for your user to be logged in with their email address instead, you can alternatively update this attribute to user.mail.
    Note: If you're using SCIM for Microsoft Entra ID, this attribute should the same as the SCIM Source attribute. By default, the SCIM Source attribute is user.userprincipalname. For more information, see the Advanced Configuration Options section of our How to Configure SCIM for Microsoft Entra ID article.
  9. Click the Save button. 
  10. In the SAML Signing Certificate section, copy the Thumbprint.
  11. In the Set up section, copy the Login URL. You'll need this in addition to the Thumbprint above. 
Note: You'll need to paste the Thumbprint and Login URL in the IdP SSO Target URL and IdP Cert Fingerprint fields when you set up SSO in your KnowBe4 account.

Assign Users to KnowBe4 in Microsoft Entra ID

After you add the KnowBe4 application to Microsoft Entra ID, you can assign users and groups to the application. 

To assign users and groups to your KnowBe4 application, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Microsoft Entra ID admin account. 
  2. Navigate to Enterprise applications > All applications.
  3. Select the KnowBe4 application. 
  4. From the navigation panel, select the Users and groups tab.
  5. Click the + Add user button.
  6. Select the users or groups that you would like to assign to your KnowBe4 application.
  7. Click the Select button. 
  8. Once you've added all the users or groups you would like to add, click the Assign button.

Configure Microsoft Entra ID in Your KnowBe4 Account

To complete the configuration, you'll need to enter your Microsoft Entra ID Login URL and Thumbprint into your KnowBe4 Account Settings.

To learn how to enter this information into your Account Settings, see our How to Set Up SAML Single Sign-on for the Security Awareness Training Platform article.

Create a New Certificate and Update Thumbprint

Each time your Microsoft Entra ID SAML certificate expires, you'll need to create and activate a new certificate. Then, you'll need to update the SAML thumbprint in your KnowBe4 account. 

To create a new certificate and update your thumbprint, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Microsoft Entra ID admin account. 
  2. Navigate to Enterprise applications > All applications.
  3. Select the KnowBe4 application. 
  4. From the navigation panel, select the Single sign-on tab.
  5. In the SAML Signing Certificate section of the page, click the pencil icon.
  6. Click the + New Certificate button.
  7. Select the calendar icon.
  8. Select the date that you would like your certificate to expire on.
  9. Click the Save button.
  10. Click the three dots icon next to the certificate you've created.
  11. Click the Make certificate active button.
  12. In the Thumbprint column, copy your new thumbprint. In step 5 below, you'll need to paste this thumbprint into your KnowBe4 account.

Next, you'll need to update your thumbprint in your KnowBe4 account by following the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account. 
  2. In the top-right corner of the page, click your email address.
  3. Select Account Settings. 
  4. Navigate to Account Integrations > SAML.
  5. Paste your new certificate thumbprint into the IdP Cert Fingerprint field. 
  6. Scroll down to the bottom of the page. 
  7. Click the Save Changes button.  
Note: Make sure the email address that your users use to authenticate with SAML is either entered into the Email or Email Aliases field of their User Profile. However, only the email address listed in the Email field will receive training notification emails. For more information about adding information to user profiles, see our User Profile Guide.

articles.name: Training Reports Guide
articles.title: Training Reports Guide
articles.body:
In your KnowBe4 account, you can view reports about your users' training progress. These reports include information such as how many users have completed their training content, how many users have not completed their training content, and how many users have acknowledged assigned policies. To access training reports, log in to your KnowBe4 account and navigate to Training > Reports.

Click the links below to learn about the different types of data you can view from your training reports. For more information about managing and monitoring training campaigns, see our Creating and Managing Training Campaigns article or our Monitoring Training Campaigns video.

Tip:We also offer a variety of reports through our Reporting feature. For more information about our Reporting feature, see our KSAT Reporting Guide.

Sign-up Reports

The Sign-up Reports section of the Reports subtab contains two reports: Users Who Have Logged In and Users Who Have Never Logged In. To view a report, click the View Report button under the report name. To download a CSV file of a report, click the CSV button under the report name.

The Users Who Have Logged In report lists your users’ email addresses when their account was created, and when they last logged in to their account.

The Users Who Have Never Logged In report lists your users’ email addresses and when their account was created.

Tip:If you would like to resend an account registration link to your users, navigate to your Dashboard. Then, copy the link at the bottom of the Training tile and send the link to your users.Alternatively, you can also send your users a notification to create their accounts. For more information about notifications, see our Training Campaign Notifications article (screenshot below).

Content Reports

In the Content Reports section of the Reports subtab, you can view a report to see which users have completed specific training content. You can filter this report by training courses, user groups, and timeframe. For more information about the filters you can apply to your report, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Content: Click this drop-down menu to select one or more content items that you would like to include in your report.
    Important:To view your report, you must select at least one content item from this drop-down menu.
  2. Users: Click this drop-down menu to select one or more user groups that you would like to include in your report.
  3. Start: Click the calendar icon to select a start date.
  4. End: Click the calendar icon to select an end date.
  5. Include Archived Users: Enable this setting if you would like to include any archived users in your report.
